questions.question: Which of the following statements about the spleen is not true?

options.B: The long axis lies along the 10th rib.
options.C: It develops from the mesenchymal cells of the ventral mesogastrium.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) It develops from the mesenchymal cells of the ventral mesogastrium. embryogenesis. Anatomy of spleen: Weight: 75 to 250 gm (Option A ruled out) Location: left hypochondrium, along the axis of the 10th rib. (Option B ruled out) It is an intraperitoneal organ. (Option D ruled out) Largest lymphatic organ In a healthy adult, the spleen is not usually palpable. It becomes palpable when the size increases by more than 2.5 times. Suspended by two ligaments: lienorenal ligament and gastrosplenic ligament. Relations of the spleen: Related to the 9th, 10th, and 11th rib, with its long axis along the 10th rib. It is related to the fundus of the stomach, the tail of the pancreas, the splenic flexure of the colon, and the anterior surface of the left kidney on it’s visceral surface. Two important ligaments that keep it in place are gastrosplenic and splenorenal ligaments . Physiology: Hematopoietic: During embryonic development. Reservoir: It pools in platelets Filtration: removal of senescent cells, cellular inclusions (RBC nucleoli), and parasites, and the sequestration of RBCs (for maturation). Immunity: It processes foreign antigens and is the major site of specific immunoglobulin (IgM) production. Synthesis of non-specific opsonins, properdin and tuftsin takes place.

questions.question: What is the most common indication for a splenectomy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Trauma Explanation: Splenic trauma is the most common indication for splenectomy. Indications for splenectomy: Trauma: Accidental, Iatrogenic Hematological: Spherocytosis, Purpura (ITP), Hypersplenism Portal hypertension: Variceal bleed, surgery Oncological: Part of en bloc resection, Diagnostic, Therapeutic Most common indication- Trauma (Option C) Most common indication of elective splenectomy- ITP (Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura) (Option B ruled out) Always indicated in: Grade V splenic injury Primary splenic tumor Hereditary spherocytosis (Option A ruled out) Usually indicated in: Chronic ITP Abscess (Option D ruled out) Splenic vein thrombosis leading to gastric varices Primary hypersplenism Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) Low benefit: Thalassaemia Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) Gaucher's disease Hodgkin's lymphoma for staging laparotomy Sickle cell anemia Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, pg 1223-1229, SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th edition, pg 669. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560824/

questions.question: A 45-year-old male is planned for an elective splenectomy due to hereditary spherocytosis. Which of the following vaccination strategies is most appropriate to prevent infections post-splenectomy?

options.B: Only if the patient shows signs of infection
options.C: Delay all vaccinations until 6 months after surgery
options.D: At least one week before the surgery

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) At least one week before the surgery Explanation: At least one week before the surgery is the correct and most evidence-based timing for vaccination before elective splenectomy. This allows the patient’s immune system sufficient time to generate protective antibody responses, especially against encapsulated organisms , which pose a serious infection risk after splenectomy. Key vaccines to administer: Pneumococcal vaccine (preferably PCV13 followed by PPSV23) Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) vaccine Meningococcal vaccine (covering groups A, C, W, and Y; MenB as needed) Annual influenza vaccination is also recommended Vaccination Recommendations for Asplenic Patients: Vaccine Children Adults ( ≥ 19 years) Pneumococcal PCV13 → PPSV23 (8 weeks later) → Repeat PPSV23 after 5 years PCV13 → PPSV23 (8 weeks later) → Repeat PPSV23 every 5 years Meningococcal MenACWY series + MenB series MenACWY or MPSV4 (2 doses, 2 months apart) → Repeat MenACWY every 5 years + MenB series once Haemophilus influenzae type b Single dose if ≥ 15 months and unvaccinated Single dose if not previously vaccinated Timing of Vaccination: Scenario Recommendation Elective splenectomy (ideal) 10–12 weeks before surgery (optimal for immune response) Elective splenectomy (minimum) At least 2 weeks before surgery Emergency splenectomy At hospital discharge or 14 days post-op, whichever comes first Additional CDC-Recommended Vaccinations: As per CDC 2020 guidelines , the following should also be considered based on age and risk factors: Influenza (annually) Tdap or Td HPV MMR Varicella Zoster Hepatitis A and B Key Points: Encapsulated organisms (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae , Neisseria meningitidis , Haemophilus influenzae ) pose high infection risk post-splenectomy. Vaccination significantly reduces the risk of Overwhelming Post-Splenectomy Infection (OPSI) . Booster doses and lifelong follow-up are essential. 10–12 weeks before surgery (Option A) is incorrect because such an early window is not necessary . Vaccines should ideally be administered at least 2 weeks before elective splenectomy, with a minimum of 1 week still being acceptable. Only if the patient shows signs of infection (Option B) is incorrect because vaccines are prophylactic , not therapeutic. Waiting for infection defeats their preventive purpose. Delay all vaccinations until 6 months after surgery (Option C) is incorrect because this would leave the patient highly susceptible to life-threatening infections , especially overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI), during the critical early period post-op.

questions.question: An elderly male undergoes an open splenectomy due to splenic rupture following a car accident. In the postoperative room, he complains of shortness of breath and chest discomfort. What is the MOST common immediate complication after a splenectomy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Left basal atelectasis Explanation: Left lobe atelectasis is the most common complication after a splenectomy. Complications after splenectomy: Short-term complications: Postoperative bleeding: Slipped ligature from the hilar vessels or short gastric vessels. Pneumonia (Option D ruled out) Left-sided pleural effusion (Option C ruled out) Pancreatic leak and fistula Left lobe atelectasis (Option B) Gastric perforation at the greater curvature and gastric fistula Post-splenectomy thrombosis of the splenic, mesenteric, and portal veins (PST-SMPv) Left subphrenic abscess Acute pancreatitis from injury to the tail of the pancreas Septicemia Late complications: Post-splenectomy thrombosis of the splenic, mesenteric, and portal veins (PST-SMPv). DVT/Pulmonary embolism (Option A ruled out) - due to post-splenectomy thrombosis and prolonged immobility. Overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI): Most common and fatal late complication. Septicemia Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page 1230, 1231. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560824/

questions.question: A 25-year-old woman with thalassemia major undergoes an elective splenectomy. She is informed about potential complications and the need for vaccinations. When is the most common Fatal late complication of splenectomy most likely to occur?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 2-5 years post-splenectomy Explanation: Overwhelming Post-Splenectomy Infection (OPSI) is the most common fatal late complication usually seen after 2-5 years after splenectomy. Overwhelming Post-Splenectomy Infection (OPSI): Causative organisms: Polysaccharide encapsulated organisms like S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, and H. influenzae. Most common organism is S. pneumoniae Risk factors for OPSI: Young age Thalassemia major (8.2%) Sickle cell anemia (7.3%) Idiopathic thrombocytopenia (2.1%) Lymphoma Immunosuppression Mortality rate: 40% and 50% OPSI is easier to prevent but difficult to treat. Prevention: Vaccination Time for vaccination: Ideally- 10-12 weeks before surgery At least 2 weeks before an elective surgery Emergency splenectomy- At discharge or 14 days after surgery whichever is first. Treatment: Broad-spectrum antibiotics and supportive care. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, pg 1579, 1580

questions.question: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with a history of sudden onset of petechial hemorrhages and purpuric patches on the skin. The mother also reports episodes of spontaneous epistaxis over the past few days. He had a flu-like illness a few weeks ago. Laboratory investigations show isolated thrombocytopenia. Which of the following symptoms is most likely to be seen in this patient?

options.A: Equal incidence in both males and females

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Equal incidence in both males and females Explanation: Acute ITP typically presents in children under the age of 5 and affects both males and females equally. The sudden onset of petechiae, purpura, and spontaneous bleeding are characteristic features. Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) Definition : An autoimmune disease where antibodies attack platelet membrane glycoproteins, leading to isolated thrombocytopenia. Types : Acute ITP : Occurs in children. Chronic ITP : Occurs in adults. Clinical Features Chronic ITP : More common in women aged 15-50. Can affect any age or sex. Acute ITP : Typically presents before age 5. Affects males and females equally. (Option A) Symptoms : Skin & Mucous Membranes : Purpuric patches (ecchymoses), petechial hemorrhages. Mucous Membranes : Spontaneous bleeding (e.g., epistaxis). Women : Menorrhagia. General : Prolonged bleeding from minor wounds. Diagnosis of ITP Diagnostic Feature Finding Palpable Spleen Uncommon in ITP; may suggest an alternative diagnosis Coagulation Studies Normal Bleeding Time Tests Not useful in diagnosing ITP Cutaneous Ecchymoses Present Tourniquet Test Positive Complete Blood Count Reduced platelet count (< 60 x 10 I /L) Bone Marrow Aspiration Increased megakaryocytes Renal dysfunction (Option C) : is not a feature of ITP but is more characteristic of conditions like Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) or Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP). Hemolytic anemia and jaundice (Option D) : are associated with conditions like TTP or HUS, not ITP, where isolated thrombocytopenia is the primary finding. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Pages 1226, 1227

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with persistent petechiae, frequent nosebleeds, and heavy menstrual bleeding over the past 7 months. She is being considered for splenectomy. Which statement accurately reflects the current approach to this treatment?

options.B: Long-term steroid therapy is the primary approach.
options.C: Approximately 50% of patients will achieve complete remission post-splenectomy.
options.D: All patients receive pre-splenectomy transfusions immediately

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Laparoscopic splenectomy is preferred. Explanation: The patient's symptoms—persistent petechiae, frequent nosebleeds, and heavy menstrual bleeding—suggest chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) . Chronic ITP is defined by a platelet count below normal for more than 6 months. Laparoscopic splenectomy is increasingly preferred due to its minimally invasive nature. In ITP, the spleen is usually normal or slightly enlarged, making laparoscopic techniques suitable. Important to identify and remove splenunculi (accessory spleens) to prevent recurrence. Treatment for ITP Acute ITP Common in children. Often resolves without treatment. Short courses of corticosteroids are effective. Prolonged steroid therapy is not recommended. Chronic ITP(>6 months) Typically affects adults. Corticosteroids are used but prolonged use is not advised. (Option B ruled out) For refractory or relapsing cases, splenectomy is generally recommended. Splenectomy Outcomes Complete remission~66% (two-thirds) (Option C ruled out) Some improvement- 15% Predictors of Success Response to steroids: Good responders are more likely to benefit from splenectomy if the disease recurs. Pre-Splenectomy Considerations Transfusions May be necessary before a splenectomy. Typically not administered until splenic vessels are controlled. (Option D ruled out) Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page 1227

questions.question: A 30-year-old patient presents with an abdominal mass. Imaging studies reveal a cystic structure in the spleen. Based on the imaging characteristics and the absence of an epithelial lining, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Secondary cysts Explanation: Secondary cysts (pseudocysts) lack an epithelial lining and often develop following trauma. They typically contain serous or hemorrhagic fluid and may have calcified walls that resemble hydatid cysts on imaging. Categories: Primary (True) Cysts: Characteristics: Presence of an epithelial lining. Types: Dermoid Cysts: Derived from embryonal rests. (Option D ruled out) Mesenchymal Inclusion Cysts: Includes cystic hemangiomas, cystic lymphangiomas, epidermoid and dermoid cysts. (Option A, Option B ruled out) Secondary Cysts (Pseudocysts): Characteristics: No epithelial lining; often develop post-trauma. Content: Serous or hemorrhagic fluid. Appearance: May have calcified walls, resembling hydatid cysts on imaging. Management: True Cysts> 5 cm: Treatment: Splenectomy or partial splenectomy. Pseudocysts: Diagnosis: Typically through imaging. Treatment: Intervention only if symptomatic or persistent after observation. Overall, the most common splenic cyst is Pseudocyst. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Pages 1221, 1222

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient undergoes a splenectomy for an incidental finding. Histological examination of the spleen reveals a vascular tumor. Which of the following is the most likely type of tumor identified?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hemangioendothelioma Explanation: Hemangioendothelioma is a type of vascular tumor that is commonly found in the spleen. It arises from endothelial cells lining blood vessels, making it a likely candidate for a vascular tumor found in the spleen. Types of Splenic Tumors Non-Lymphoid Tumors Vascular Tumors ( most common ): Benign Hemangiomas Littoral Cell Angiomas Lymphangiomas Hemangioendotheliomas Other Tumors (less common): Fibrosarcoma Neurinoma Lipoma Lymphoid Tumors Hodgkin’s Lymphoma Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma (Option C ruled out) Histiocytic Lymphoma (Option A ruled out) Plasmacytoma (Option D ruled out) Metastatic Tumors Originating from melanoma, breast cancer, and lung cancer (less common compared to other organs) Clinical Considerations Symptoms : Often asymptomatic, found incidentally Diagnosis : Histological examination post-surgery is the most reliable Management : Essential due to potential malignancy and complications Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3614769/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3578545/

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with a one-week history of persistent left upper abdominal pain. The patient exhibits fever, left upper quadrant tenderness, and leukocytosis. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for confirming the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Computed Tomography (CT) Explanation: Based on the clinical presentation of a 45-year-old patient with a one-week history of persistent left upper abdominal pain, fever, left upper quadrant tenderness, and leukocytosis, the most likely diagnosis is a splenic abscess . Computed Tomography (CT) is the investigation of choice with nearly 100% sensitivity for diagnosing splenic abscesses. It reveals low-density lesions that do not enhance with contrast and provides detailed information on size, location, and access routes. Causes of Splenic Abscess: Infected splenic emboli Infections: Typhoid, paratyphoid fever, osteomyelitis, otitis media, puerperal sepsis Complications from pancreatic necrosis or other intra-abdominal infections Potential Complications: Rupture: May lead to Left subphrenic abscess Diffuse peritonitis Laboratory Studies: Complete Blood Count (CBC): Leukocytosis (WBC count >20,000/ µ L) with left shift Immunocompromised patients may show different results Recurrent Positive Blood Cultures Imaging Studies: Type Findings Radiography (Option A ruled out) Chest X-ray: Non-specific for splenic abscess; may show: Elevated left hemidiaphragm (>30%) Pleural effusion (>20%) Abdominal X-ray : Non-specific; possible findings include: Abnormal soft-tissue density Gas collection in the left upper quadrant Nuclear Studies (Option D ruled out) Radioisotope scanning: Limited value due to long test duration Ultrasonography (Option B ruled out) Cost-effective and non-invasive, but: Nonspecific and operator-dependent Computed Tomography (CT) (Option C) Criterion standard for diagnosing splenic abscess Procedures: Diagnostic Percutaneous Aspiration: Guided by US or CT to confirm diagnosis and obtain specimens for bacteriology Differentiation from Primary Splenic Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL): May require splenic biopsy and immunohistochemical staining for accurate diagnosis Treatment Approaches: Address underlying cause Percutaneous drainage (guided by imaging) Splenectomy is reserved for cases where percutaneous drainage is not feasible Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Pg 1224 https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/194655-workup?form=fpf#c5
